question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Steve guesses randomly on a 15-question multiple choice test in which each problem has two choices, a correct one and an incorrect one. What is the probability that he gets at least half of the questions correct? Express your answer as a common fraction.
inference:
The probability of getting a question correct is 1/2. The probability of getting a question wrong is also 1/2.
The probability of getting at least half of the questions correct is the sum of the probabilities of getting exactly half of the questions correct, exactly half of the questions correct plus one, and so on, up to getting all of the questions correct.
The probability of getting exactly half of the questions correct is (1/2)^15.
The probability of getting exactly half of the questions correct plus one is (1/2)^14 * (1/2).
The probability of getting exactly half of the questions correct plus two is (1/2)^13 * (1/2)^2.
And so on.
The sum of these probabilities is
(1/2)^15 + (1/2)^14 * (1/2) + (1/2)^13 * (1/2)^2 + ... + (1/2)^0 * (1/2)^15
= (1/2)^15 * [1 + (1/2) + (1/2)^2 + ... + (1/2)^15]
= (1/2)^15 * [(1 - (1/2)^16)/(1 - (1/2))]
= (1/2)^15 * [(1 - (1/2)^16)/((1/2))]
= (1/2)^15 * [(1 - (1/2)^16)/((1/2))]
= (1 - (1/2)^16)
= 1 - (1/32768)
= 32767/32768
Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{32767}{32768}}. \space\space I \space hope \space it \space is \space correct.$
ground_truth: Steve cannot get exactly half the questions right since there are an odd number of questions. So he can get either more than half or less than half correct, with equal probability, since he has a $1/2$ chance of getting any individual question correct. This means that Steve has a probability of $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$ of getting more than half correct, or identically, at least half correct.
